docs.snippet: As the Philippine president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, was embraced at the World Economic Forum in New York as a standout leader willing to accept American troops to fight terrorists, influential critics at home persisted  over the weekend in askin...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the Philippine president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, was embraced at the World Economic Forum in New York as a standout leader willing to accept American troops to fight terrorists, influential critics at home persisted over the weekend in asking what the Americans would really be doing. At the heart of the concern is this: Will the Americans be fighting? And with the Filipino sensitivity about sovereignty, under whose command will the Americans be?
docs.abstract: Philippine Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's willingness to accept American troops to fight terrorists has raised questions among influential critics at home, over what role Americans will play since Constitution forbids foreign combat troops; Bush administration describes presence of American troops as training exercise in which 650 soldiers, including 150 Special forces, will advise Philippine Army how to fight Abu Sayyaf, Islamic militants holding American missionaries Martin and Gracia Burnham hostage on Basilan Island (M)

headline.main: Role of U.S. Forces Vexes Filipinos, Who Have a Sensitivity About Sovereignty

docs.snippet: The midnight raid against two Taliban leadership compounds north of Kandahar on Thursday uncovered one of the largest ammunition depots to survive the American air campaign undetected by coalition intelligence, military officials said today.    Th...
docs.lead_paragraph: The midnight raid against two Taliban leadership compounds north of Kandahar on Thursday uncovered one of the largest ammunition depots to survive the American air campaign undetected by coalition intelligence, military officials said today. The cache included more than a half million bullets for small arms, 400 60-millimeter mortar rounds, 300 rocket-propelled grenades, some 300 100-millimeter rockets and more than 250 automatic grenade-launcher rounds, said Rear Adm. John D. Stufflebeem, deputy director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
docs.abstract: Rear Adm John D Stufflebeem reports raid on two Taliban leadership compounds north of Kandahar by American special operations forces uncovered large ammunition depot unknown to coalition intelligence; reports up to 15 Taliban soldiers were killed and 27 others captured (M)

headline.main: Arms Cache Uncovered In U.S. Raid On 2 Camps

docs.snippet: The United States military is revising a risky plan for American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora for traces of Osama bin Laden and other fighters of Al Qaeda, and is offering incentives to get Afghan forces to take the lead, American offic...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States military is revising a risky plan for American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora for traces of Osama bin Laden and other fighters of Al Qaeda, and is offering incentives to get Afghan forces to take the lead, American officials said today. Just last Friday, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said he was ordering hundreds more troops to join Afghan militia in the hunt for Mr. bin Laden and other Qaeda leaders, in the hope of uncovering intelligence on terror attacks in the works. Officials said then that the plan was to send in about 500 marines and possibly Army troops, and the units began to prepare for the mission.
docs.abstract: United States revises risky plan for US troops to search Tora Bora, Afghanistan, caves for traces of Osama bin Laden and other Al Qaeda fighters; is offering incentives to get Afghan forces to take lead; will send more troops if Afghans balk; US effort would require building and maintenance of substantial base to house troops in area where anti-American sentiment lingers (M)

headline.main: U.S. PUTTING OFF PLAN TO USE G.I.'S IN AFGHAN CAVES

byline.original: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with ERIC SCHMITT

docs.snippet: A senior Afghan official said today that American reluctance to provide security for the former Afghan king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, set off the events that led him to postpone his return to his homeland after 29 years in exile in Italy.    The Afgha...
docs.lead_paragraph: A senior Afghan official said today that American reluctance to provide security for the former Afghan king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, set off the events that led him to postpone his return to his homeland after 29 years in exile in Italy. The Afghan official said American officials had told Italian counterparts last week that Italy, not the United States, should take responsibility for the former king's security after his return to Kabul, which was to have taken place today.
docs.abstract: Afghan official blames United States's reported stand that Italy, not US, should provide security for former Afghan king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, led him to delay his return to Afghanistan from in exile in Italy; US denies Pres Bush expressed reluctance to protect king in phone call to Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi asking Italy to continue to contribute to Afghanistan effort; delay apparently embarrasses interim leader Hamid Karzai, royalist who played key role in persuading Zahir to return; photo (M)

headline.main: Afghan Says U.S. Posture Led to Delay By Zahir Shah

docs.snippet: Chased from the caves of Tora Bora, hundreds of Al Qaeda fighters have made their way east across the ice-slicked rocks of the White Mountains and into the untamed tribal areas of Pakistan.     There could be few better places for a fugitive to fl...
docs.lead_paragraph: Chased from the caves of Tora Bora, hundreds of Al Qaeda fighters have made their way east across the ice-slicked rocks of the White Mountains and into the untamed tribal areas of Pakistan. There could be few better places for a fugitive to flee. The Pashtuns of the region think it their duty to give sanctuary to anyone who requests it, friend or not, Muslim or not, terrorist or not.
docs.abstract: Hundreds of Al Qaeda fighters, chased from Tora Bora caves, have crossed mountains into Pakistan's untamed tribal areas; Pashtuns of remote Tirah Valley offer sanctuary to anyone who seeks it; photos (M)

headline.main: Tribal Area of Pakistan Gives Refuge to Qaeda Fighters Fleeing Caves

docs.snippet: Jennifer K. Harbury, the Harvard Law School-educated widow of a Guatemalan rebel leader, argued in the Supreme Court today for the right to sue government officials who did not tell her all they knew about his capture, torture and death at the han...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jennifer K. Harbury, the Harvard Law School-educated widow of a Guatemalan rebel leader, argued in the Supreme Court today for the right to sue government officials who did not tell her all they knew about his capture, torture and death at the hands of the Guatemalan military in the early 1990's. Ms. Harbury argued that had the officials told her that her husband, Efraín Bámaca-Velásquez, who was assumed to be dead, was being held secretly by Guatemalans working with the Central Intelligence Agency, she could have gone to court in time to intervene and save his life.
docs.abstract: Jennifer K Harbury, Harvard Law School-educated widow of Guatemalan rebel leader Efrain Bamaca-Velasquez, argues before US Supreme Court for right to sue government officials who did not tell her all they knew about his capture, torture and death at hands of Guatemalan military in early 1990's; argues that had officials of State Dept, National Security Council and CIA told her that husband, who was assumed to be dead, was being held secretly by Guatemalans working with CIA she could have gone to court in time to intervene and save his life; photo (M)

headline.main: Widow Argues for Right to Sue Officials

docs.snippet: Scores of Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners being held at the United States Naval Base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, began a protest on Wednesday after guards removed a makeshift turban from the head of a praying prisoner, military officials said today. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Scores of Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners being held at the United States Naval Base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, began a protest on Wednesday after guards removed a makeshift turban from the head of a praying prisoner, military officials said today. Today, prisoners chanted ''God is great!'' and banged water bottles and buckets inside their chain-link cages to register their anger over the incident. Military officials said guards took no action to quell the protest, which lasted 45 minutes.
docs.abstract: Scores of Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners held at United States Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, begin protest after guards remove makeshift turban from head of praying prisoner; military officials say guards took no action to quell protest; some prisoners are refusing to eat meals (M)

headline.main: Detainees Stage Protest at Base Over a Turban

docs.abstract: Photo of burial of Al Qaeda fighter who blew self up with grenade at Kandahar, Afghanistan, hospital

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Contrary to ''How to Try a Terrorist'' (editorial, Dec. 29), trying Al Qaeda leaders for violating the laws of armed conflict would not legitimize their attack on America as warfare. Article 2 of all the Geneva Conventions carefu...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Contrary to ''How to Try a Terrorist'' (editorial, Dec. 29), trying Al Qaeda leaders for violating the laws of armed conflict would not legitimize their attack on America as warfare. Article 2 of all the Geneva Conventions carefully states that the conventions apply in ''any armed conflict,'' and that application of the conventions imports nothing about whether the underlying conflict is lawful, or even war at all. Moreover, military tribunals need not limit themselves to ''military'' offenses. An Al Qaeda leader who plotted the Sept. 11 attacks could be tried for crimes against humanity, conspiracy and first-degree murder in a military tribunal.
docs.abstract: Letter by former Justice Department official Allan A Ryan Jr letter says trying Al Qaeda leaders for violating laws of armed conflict would not legitimize their attack on America; explains further that military tribunals need not limit themselves to 'military' offenses (S)

docs.snippet: After a week of intense negotiations, Afghan and British officials agreed that fewer than 100 British marines would be deployed in Kabul before a new interim government took power on Saturday, Western diplomats said tonight.    The marines will se...
docs.lead_paragraph: After a week of intense negotiations, Afghan and British officials agreed that fewer than 100 British marines would be deployed in Kabul before a new interim government took power on Saturday, Western diplomats said tonight. The marines will serve as the vanguard of an international security force that will expand to between 2,000 and 4,000 troops in the next several weeks.
docs.abstract: Afghan and British conclude week of intense negotiations with agreement to deploy fewer than 100 British marines in Kabul before interim government takes office; marines will be vanguard of international security force of 2,000-4,000 troops; small initial size is seen as victory for Northern Alliance hard-liners opposed to large foreign force; talks continue on force authority; troops will patrol with Afghans in central Kabul and on main road to Bagram Air Base; map; French, Canadian and Italian soldiers also expected; deleted clauses would have allowed Afghan soldiers to be tried for war crimesand allowed for collecting of weapons (M)

headline.main: British in Accord With Afghans On Force to Keep Order in Kabul
